docs.lead_paragraph: Like the champion of jet lag he is known to be, Dr. Paul Farmer dashed into town recently to give a seminar at Harvard Medical School. He had arrived in Boston via Haiti and Rwanda, the central African nation where he has been organizing an campaign to fight AIDS with money from the William J. Clinton Foundation. Dr. Farmer, 45, is a founding director of Partners in Health, a nonprofit agency based at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. The organization provides medical services to the poor of Haiti, Rwanda, Peru, Russia and, yes, even Boston.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: Paul Farmer; Healing the World by Curing the Poor

docs.snippet: The founding director of Partners in Health talks about the third world and the deeper causes of disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''It's a little bit in the guinea pig stage,'' Dr. Burton A. Cohen said. ''I've only tried it on four people. Are you interested?'' Dr. Cohen, a leading Manhattan radiologist, was proposing to slow down my pulse, inject iodine-based dye in my arm and photograph slices of my heart with his fastest CT scanner.

headline.main: Obstinate Patient, Insistent Doctor, New Test

docs.snippet: Show me the evidence of heart disease, he told his doctor.
